data.title: Financial
data.text:
More Thai flights to Sri Lanka

More flights: Thai Airways is planning to increase the frequencyof flights to Sri Lanka with the opening of Thailand's largest international airport Suvarnabhumi Airport towards the end of this year, said its General Manager Sri Lanka and the Republic of Maldives Suvadhana Sibunruang.

Sibunruang said that with the open sky policy between the two countries it is quite easy to increase the number of flights to Sri Lanka which currently has four flights a week.

The reason being Thai Airway's ability to increase the frequency between Sri Lanka to Thailand due to the satisfactory occupancy level of their flight.

He said that Airline has been operating in Sri Lanka for nearly 30 years has a lot of plans where Sri Lankan operations are concerned in the future.

He said that Suvarnabhumi International Airport is one of the largest airports in the Asian region, which has a passenger capacity of 45 million passengers for a year. Currently Bangkok International Airport has the passenger capacity of 30 million for a year.

He further said that they are also hoping to consider Sri Lanka as a major transit point to many destinations of the airline which flies to Maldives, India, South India and European destinations which is on the pipeline.

General Manager said that they have more than 70 per cent occupancy rate and air fair is competitive among other airlines.

Sibunruang said that Colombo is in their main route and they try to promote network sales in both way traffic.

Thai Airways is one of the most sought after airlines in the Asian region which always consider the safety and value added service to the passengers, he said.

As Sri Lanka and Thailand are Buddhist countries Sibunruang takes a special interest to promote Sri Lanka as major tourist attraction in the world while they promote the Royal Orchid holiday package to Sri Lankan tourists as well.

He also said that one of the problems encountered with promoting Sri Lanka as a tourist destination was due to the uncertain in the country. If peace prevails they could promote the island as a major tourist destination.
